results.title: Warming by the devil's fire
results.creator_credit: Charles Burnett, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. Kidnapped by Uncle Buddy, on his way to be saved from the devil by being baptised, a young 11 year-old boy gets a life education on exactly what it is he is going to be ‘saved’ from. Through a re-telling of this young boy’s journey travelling the Deep South, his education becomes the viewers’ with a narration (by Carl Lumbly) of the boy as an adult recalling this past he will never forget. The history of the African American musician is his lesson, starting out in New Orleans and the blues music that stemmed from early 1900 to the 1940s turns into, as the director says, a ‘story that gives you the impression of the blues’. Inserted in the ‘educational’ narrative is a combination of archival footage of the period, original performances and stills. The influence of the church and gospel music is covered and the work also includes details of female performers whose powerful music and voices transcend time and place, such as Bessie Smith, Victoria Spivey, Ma Rainey, Dinah Washington and Sister Rosetta Thorpe. Others featured include Willie Dixon, Sonny Boy Williamson, Son House, John Lee Hooker and Muddy Waters amongst many others. Cast includes Tommy Redmond Hicks and Nathaniel Lee Jr. with an original score by Stephen James Taylor.

results.title: Reel lives; All in the game
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series ‘The Best of British’.
Great historical characters have been portrayed on the silver screen since the movies began. The veracity of these films ranges from the authentic to sheer flights of fantasy. In ‘Reel lives’, films such as ‘The Magic bow’ starring Stewart Granger, and ‘Cleopatra’ with Vivien Leigh are examined. ‘All in the game’ discusses how sports provided just the right background to some of the most exciting British films, including the famous ‘This sporting life’ and ‘The Lady vanishes’. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The War game. Heroes
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Best of British”.
The War Game examines the British approach to war with scenes from some of the most famous movies ever made, such as” Waterloo Bridge”, “Henry V” and the “Life and times of Colonel Blimp”. “Heroes” makes the comparison between heroes of American cinema and their British counterparts. A tribute is made to the “stiff upper lip” hero played by the likes of Leslie Howard, Jack Hawkins, Stewart Granger, Alec Guinness and David Niven in a variety of roles from spy to school boy. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: Piano blues
results.creator_credit: Clint Eastwood, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. An intimate series of interviews with some of the big names in piano blues music in America with director, and fellow pianist, Clint Eastwood. Starting out with Ray Charles and featuring clips and photographs of musicians of the last century, Eastwood’s journey is sure to inspire a new generation as he asks “Who were your influences…?” Whilst guitar seems to take centre stage in modern blues, it could be argued that it was piano that lead to the popularisation of the form with hit makers such as Ray Charles, Fats Domino and Duke Ellington leading the way. Refreshingly includes some footage and interviews with female musicians. Some of the legends seen performing are: Ray Charles, Dr. John, Fats Domino, Prof. Longhair, Nat King Cole, Dave Brubeck, Marcia Ball, Jay McShann, Art Tatum, Big Joe Turner and Duke Ellington among many others.

results.title: I Spy. The English roses
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Best of British”.
I spy is a fascinating compilation of British spy films such as Alfred Hitchcock’s “The Lady vanishes”. Included is an interesting comparative analysis of the 1935, 1959 and 1978 versions of “The 39 steps.” “The English roses” spotlights six of Britain’s most beautiful and talented leading actresses in a range of roles which won the hearts of many viewers. Actresses covered include Deborah Kerr, Phyllis Calvert, Margaret Lockwood, Jean Simmons, Patricia Roc and Virginia McKenna. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: Godfathers and sons
results.creator_credit: Marc Levin, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. When immigrants from Poland and African Americans migrating north from the oppression of the south came together, some magic was made through music - in particular, the formation of Chess Records in 1950 - initially created by two Jewish brothers who were inspired listening to gospel music at a local church. Marc Levin looks at the history of blues by talking to the son of the founder of Chess, Marshall Chess and his take on music and inter-racial relations at the time. Marshall’s psychodelic inspired project Electric Mud featuring Muddy Waters is a pivotal album in the influential sphere of Chuck D from hip-hop’s Public Enemy. Exploring his roots, Chuck D, and Marshall, take a tour of Chicago and re-form the Electric Mud Group to pay homage to the ‘roots’ of blues and add their own contemporary interpretation. Marshall’s life in music went beyond the recording industry and he worked in the 1960s for seven years as Company Manager for the Rolling Stones. The take up of the blues by young white musicians in the UK and the US in the 1960s is shown - the cycle of Godfathers influencing the Sons. Features archival performance footage and includes live concert footage of the Chicago Blues Festival and the legendary Koko Taylor at her club. Howlin’ Wolf, Bob Dylan, Willie Dixon, Muddy Waters, Pinetop Perkins, and Ike Turner are some of the artists featured.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marc Levin, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)

The take up of the blues by young white musicians in the UK and the US in the 1960s is shown - the cycle of Godfathers influencing the Sons. Features archival performance footage and includes live concert footage of the Chicago Blues Festival and the legendary Koko Taylor at her club. Howlin’ Wolf, Bob Dylan, Willie Dixon, Muddy Waters, Pinetop Perkins, and Ike Turner are some of the artists featured.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. When immigrants from Poland and African Americans migrating north from the oppression of the south came together, some magic was made through music - in particular, the formation of Chess Records in 1950 - initially created by two Jewish brothers who were inspired listening to gospel music at a local church. Marc Levin looks at the history of blues by talking to the son of the founder of Chess, Marshall Chess and his take on music and inter-racial relations at the time. Marshall’s psychodelic inspired project Electric Mud featuring Muddy Waters is a pivotal album in the influential sphere of Chuck D from hip-hop’s Public Enemy. Exploring his roots, Chuck D, and Marshall, take a tour of Chicago and re-form the Electric Mud Group to pay homage to the ‘roots’ of blues and add their own contemporary interpretation. Marshall’s life in music went beyond the recording industry and he worked in the 1960s for seven years as Company Manager for the Rolling Stones. The take up of the blues by young white musicians in the UK and the US in the 1960s is shown - the cycle of Godfathers influencing the Sons. Features archival performance footage and includes live concert footage of the Chicago Blues Festival and the legendary Koko Taylor at her club. Howlin’ Wolf, Bob Dylan, Willie Dixon, Muddy Waters, Pinetop Perkins, and Ike Turner are some of the artists featured.

results.title: All at sea; Film fun
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Best of British”.
All at sea focuses on the fine English tradition for “messing about in boats.” This episode explores action on the high sea from intrepid explorers like Columbus to heroes in submarines, as well as those heroic sea sagas and comic “fun on the ocean waves” films. “Film fun” highlights the visual comedy from Britain’s rich source of comedians such as Norman Wisdom, Frankie Howard, Peter Sellers and the Carry On crew who demonstrate the art of immaculate timing and pure visual technique. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
results.brief_description: The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them before staging performances like The Blind Man of Siloam.

constellations_primary.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_primary.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

results.description: The Salvation Army isn’t just a part of Melbourne’s social fabric – it’s also an integral part of moving-image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in elaborate sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique re-created ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns, as well as hymns, music, motion-picture segments and rousing narration.
description_for_label: The Salvation Army isn’t just a part of Melbourne’s social fabric – it’s also an integral part of moving-image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in elaborate sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique re-created ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns, as well as hymns, music, motion-picture segments and rousing narration.
